title: Boris Johnson: Tory darling with lots of problems
text:
MANCHESTER, England — Boris Johnson faces trouble on every front, but to the Conservative grassroots, he is the hero they've been waiting for.

For years, when he was mayor of London, and later as a backbench MP and minister, Johnson's appearances at the Conservative Party's annual conference were box office events. Delegates queued for at least an hour last year to see their darling.

Now prime minister and party boss, Johnson arrived in Manchester for the event, which runs until Wednesday, amid a flurry of further accusations about his conduct — both personal and political — with a party willing him to change their fortunes.

While opponents decry his aggressive approach to Brexit — which has seen him lose every vote he has faced in the House of Commons since becoming leader, fail in his bid to stop MPs passing a law that seeks to block a no-deal Brexit, and see his five-week suspension of parliament ruled unlawful by the U.K.'s top court — the prime minister shows no sign of backing down from a strategy that his team say is working.

“We have more members than ever before and more young people than ever before coming along, so it’s going to be a really positive, upbeat conference,” said Pamela Hall, the president of the Conservative grassroots board who chairs the conference. “I’ve never known us as united as we are at the moment. Everybody is fully behind the prime minister.”

Andrew Colborne-Baber, who chairs the party board on memberships, announced Sunday morning that the party has 189,000 members, up from around 130,000 in early 2018. He attributed the boost in part to a new database which was more effective at preventing memberships from lapsing and also to Johnson. “There are a lot of people coming on board since the leadership election,” he said.

Polls, too, look largely positive for the prime minister, with an Opinium survey for the Observer reporting the Tories holding a 12-point lead over Labour.

Johnson was greeted with a hero’s welcome on Sunday morning when he gave a surprise address to the National Conservative Convention of local party chairs and other senior campaigners. He received a standing ovation before he had uttered a word, telling the party faithful there would be a general election “as soon as the chickens waddle out of the coop” — a reference to opposition parties who have, thus far, refused to back a vote.

“The mood was absolutely buoyant,” said one association chair. “He is our glorious leader!”

Asked whether he has a plan for the U.K. leaving on October 31 — even if he could not secure a deal with Brussels by then, and despite the new law which would force him to seek an extension to negotiations without one — Johnson implied that he does but declined to share it.

“I don’t want to see him break the law,” said the association chair. “But because of the MPs, he can’t move, he’s totally snookered in. But I still think he’ll find a loophole.”

To the ballot box

Members also appeared confident about Tory prospects at an election, even if Johnson does end up having to break his key promise to take the U.K. out of the European Union by October 31 "do or die."

Some MPs fear that in such a scenario, the Conservative vote would be vulnerable to Nigel Farage’s Brexit Party. But if Johnson is seen by Leave voters to have strained every sinew to pull the U.K. out of the EU by the end of October, the Brexit Party could still be thwarted. “If Boris looks like he’s done everything he can, we’ll be OK,” said one senior Brexiteer MP.

The party even mocked up its own newspaper front page-come-donation plea, to hand out around the conference, with the main story, headlined “Brexit to finally be delivered,” about Johnson winning a fresh mandate from the country. A second fantasy story described Labour going “back to the drawing board” with the resignation of Jeremy Corbyn.

“People are feeling very bullish,” said another senior grassroots Tory when asked about an election.

However, some harbor concerns Johnson could sell out some Tory seats by agreeing a non-aggression electoral pact with the Brexit Party. Farage took out his own double-page advert in the Sunday Telegraph — the newspaper of the Conservative heartlands which used to employ Johnson as a star columnist — reiterating his offer if Johnson delivers a no-deal Brexit.

Members wanted to know whether the Tories would rule out a pact with Farage during the NCC meeting, according to a senior Tory in the room, and there was relief when party chairman James Cleverly ruled it out.

In a bid to keep the membership onside, new initiatives at the conference including policy debates and question sessions with Cabinet ministers have been added to the agenda in the hope of giving the rank and file more buy-in to an event which for years has been little more than a beauty parade of senior figures making dull speeches.

Moderates bite their tongue

Even among Tory moderates, criticism is muted, despite Johnson kicking 21 of their faction out of the party in pursuit of his aggressive Brexit strategy.

At a reception for One Nation Conservatives, a caucus of around 100 MPs on the left of the party, Culture Secretary Nicky Morgan, who chaired the group until she joined Johnson's Cabinet, urged them to stay in the party.

“The prime minister absolutely is a One Nation conservative. He is a social liberal,” she said.

She added the party should be “very comfortable” with Johnson's recent domestic policy announcements, including liberalizing rules for international students and investing in public services, and said she was “fully subscribed” to the conference slogan: Get Brexit Done.

“If we can get Brexit done, we can then talk about the issues that the rest of the country want us to talk about,” she said.

The only note of caution at the event came when David Gauke, one of the anti-no-deal MPs who was booted out of the party, warned the Conservatives would “have to make a choice as to what sort of party we are” in the coming weeks.

“We don’t sound like the party of Churchill or even Margaret Thatcher who, robust and radical as she was, believed passionately in our institutions, and would never undermine the importance of our parliament or our legal system,” he said. “We don’t sound like the party of Major or Cameron or May, instead ... we sound like the party of Trump — populist, confrontational and divisive.”

Some in the room said “hear, hear.”

Big problems loom

Nevertheless, big risks loom in the shadows.

Johnson is facing questions about two alleged scandals. Several official investigations, including one by police, have been launched into whether he improperly funneled public funds to Jennifer Arcuri, a businesswoman and former model he was close to during his time as mayor of London. “Everything was done in accordance with the code and everything was done with full propriety,” the prime minister told the BBC's Andrew Marr Sunday.

Journalist Charlotte Edwardes on Sunday accused Johnson of inappropriately touching her leg at a lunch when he was editor of the Spectator back in 1999. “Under the table I feel Johnson’s hand on my thigh,” she wrote in the Sunday Times. “He gives it a squeeze. His hand is high up my leg and he has enough inner flesh beneath his fingers to make me sit suddenly upright.”

After a day of fielding questions about the claim, a Downing Street spokesman told journalists on Sunday evening: “These allegations are untrue.” Edwardes tweeted that she stands by her story.

The bitterness over Brexit, which has intensified since the Supreme Court overturned the suspension of parliament, has eroded trust between the parties. The usual conference-season truce is forgotten, and opposition leaders will meet on Monday to mull ways of frustrating the Tory gathering.

Any surprise House of Commons votes could see Tory MPs flocking back to Westminster — throwing carefully planned speaking slots and fringe events into chaos. Liz Saville Roberts, the Westminster leader of Plaid Cymru, has revealed she and cross-party colleagues are looking into whether the prime minister could be impeached. The Scottish National Party, meanwhile, wants to call a vote of no confidence in the prime minister as soon as possible.

For all the optimism, Johnson has plenty of problems.
description: Despite widespread criticism about his personal and political conduct, the British prime minister is greeted as a hero by his party faithful at their annual gathering.
